bibl.author: Richard Maurice Bucke
bibl.title: Richard Maurice Bucke to Walt Whitman, 6 April 1889
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p: I have had the Inspector here since thursday evening—he went East (to Toronto) this morning. All quiet again and nobody hurt—This morning I got the little bundle of papers (Aug. 87) from you, many thanks. We have had another fall of snow yesterday and last night, quite a lot came down, several inches. It is now (under the influence of quite a warm sun) departing as rapidly as it came, by tomorrow evening (if the weather keeps as now) it will be all gone. I am still reading Brockden Brown and he interest me a good deal, more than I had expected. No letters from any of our friends and no news. I trust you are easier—I wish I could in any way make you more comfortable, perhaps by & by I shall be able
